learning_outcomes.description: Formulate a clear research topic and question relevant to mental health.
Critically review and synthesise relevant literature to justify the research question and significance.
Select and justify an appropriate research paradigm and methodological approach suitable to the topic, including ethical considerations and approval as necessary.
Engage effectively with supervision to support research planning, ethical awareness, and project development.

assessments.task_description:
Students will deliver a brief 5-minute oral proposal outlining their intended research topic, their emerging research question(s), and the research paradigm shaping their early thinking. The proposal should clearly describe the research topic and the question the student intends to answer, highlight its relevance to mental health practice, and explain its specific application within psychotherapy and/or art therapy.

An additional Q&A component will enable students to demonstrate authentic authorship and meaningful engagement with their developing research ideas.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
Students will deliver a 5-minute oral defence of their proposed research project. The defence should outline the project aims, research question(s), proposed methodology, participant or data sources, and feasibility considerations.

Students may choose to use PowerPoint slides to support the structure and communication of their presentation.

To support their oral defence, students will submit a brief written project overview (approximately 200-250 words). This overview will summarise the study gap driving the project, the research question(s), and the proposed methodological and feasibility plan. 

The oral defence will include a Q&A component in which students respond to questions about their proposal. The purpose of this assessment is to verify authentic authorship, evaluate conceptual and methodological understanding, and determine readiness to progress into thesis work. 

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

assessments.task_description:
The research proposal sets out the rationale for your research project and explains how it will be implemented. The proposal must demonstrate that the project is worth undertaking (i.e., has theoretical and/or practical significance) and that it can be accomplished within the timeframe available.

The proposal should include a written Introduction (approximately 2,500 words) that offers a literature review, a clear statement of the research question(s), and a rationale that identifies the study gap driving the project.

A brief methodological proposal section should outline the proposed design, participant or data source selection, planned procedures, ethical considerations, and a feasibility overview that includes a project timeline (Gantt chart), bringing the total submission to approximately 3,000 words.

Students should consult the rubric on Learn.UQ (Blackboard) for detailed marking expectations.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to submit an electronic copy of two artwork pieces along with the title, media used, dimensions, and a short statement (approx. 40 words) about each piece. These pieces should represent a reflection on the research process, made from your position as a student researcher.

Note:

At the end of the research courses (in semester 2), Art Therapy students will create and exhibit a minimum of six and maximum of ten art works. These 6 -10 pieces of art should link together and provide a reflection throughout the research process. You can use any materials but be cognisant of the confines of the exhibition space. Please speak to the Course Coordinator (Dani Walsh) for details.

The two artworks submitted for this assessment hurdle can be included in the final 6-10 submitted for the exhibition.

assessments.task_description:
You are allocated a research supervisor for six hours of supervision per semester.

To pass this assessment piece you will be required to attend a minimum of 3 supervisory meetings with your research supervisor to discuss your project. To ensure optimal research process, it is recommended that the meetings be held in a regular pattern (for example once every fortnight) rather than all at the near proposal submission period.

Your supervisor will evaluate your engagement with the research process and your use of supervision throughout the course. It is designed to recognise the professional and reflective capacities that underpin high-quality research practice.

Your supervisor will assess how you:

  • Demonstrate preparedness, initiative, and professionalism in supervisory meetings
  • Engage with feedback and integrated it meaningfully into your evolving project
  • Show increasing reflective awareness and self-direction across the semester
  • Maintain ethical awareness and research integrity throughout the project


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Please refer to UQs AI guidelines here.
